byline.contributor: Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Karam Shoumali contributed reporting from Istanbul, Maher Samaan from Beirut, and Steven Lee Myers from Washington.
byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI, ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: Russia's success in proxy war in Syria, at expense of United States-backed rebels, is giving country new leverage in decisions about future of Middle East; Obama administration has entered talks with Pres Vladimir Putin's goverment over plan to share intelligence and coordinate fight against Islamic State, but Pres Obama expresses wariness about collaborating with Moscow.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Russia has not only avoided a quagmire in Syria, its successes on the battlefield against C.I.A.-backed rebels have given it new leverage in the Middle East.
snippet: Russia has not only avoided a quagmire in Syria, its successes on the battlefield against C.I.A.-backed rebels have given it new leverage in the Middle East....

headline.main: Military Success in Syria Gives Putin Upper Hand in U.S. Proxy War
headline.print_headline: Military Success  in Syria Is Giving Putin Leverage
